snippet: Capt. Amadou Haya Sanogo, who led a coup in March, spoke of a continuing role in public life for the junta, which he called “the committee.”
abstract: Mali's new military junta fights back an attempted countercoup by loyalist troops; victory signals that the junta may be continuing to consolidate its control of the government, despite pledges to restore civilian rule and democracy. Photos (M)2
lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali -- This onetime model of African stability remained in a precarious state on Tuesday as the new military junta fought back an attempted countercoup by loyalist troops and asserted victory by day's end. Hours before the revolt broke out Monday, the junta's leader, a youthful American-trained captain named Amadou Haya Sanogo confidently declared a leading role in Mali's future in an interview at his barracks outside Bamako, the capital. There was no hint that his authority would be challenged later in the day, but soldiers were busy building a substantial protective wall in front of the dilapidated two-story military building that is his headquarters.

headline.main: Mali Uprising Proves No Threat to Junta Leader's Vision of Authority
